The Sandbag Suitcase Carry targets your core (obliques, abdominals, lower back), grip (forearms), shoulders, and hip stabilizers, forcing them to work isometrically to counteract the uneven weight, enhancing balance, posture, and functional strength through anti-lateral flexion. This movement pattern emphasizes unilateral loading, engaging muscles on one side intensely to maintain an upright, stable posture while walking, mimicking real-life lifting and carrying. [1, 2, 3, 4]  
Muscles Worked 

• Core: Obliques, transverse abdominis, rectus abdominis (bracing isometrically). 
• Grip & Forearms: Intense engagement to hold the bag. 
• Shoulders (Deltoids): Stabilize the weight. 
• Hip Stabilizers: Glutes and hip abductors on the loaded side. 
• Upper Back & Lower Back: To keep the spine neutral. 
• Legs: Quadriceps, hamstrings, and calves work to propel you forward. [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]

Movement Pattern 

• Anti-Lateral Flexion: The primary pattern, where core muscles contract isometrically to prevent your torso from bending toward the weighted side, says this article from the National Federation of Professional Trainers (https://nfpt.com/suitcase-carries-how-to-do/) and this Facebook post (https://www.facebook.com/justinagustinFB/posts/the-suitcase-carry-exercise-strengthens-the-core-by-loading-one-side-of-the-body/861852099273834/). 
• Unilateral Loading: Weight is on one side, challenging balance and stability more than bilateral carries (like Farmer's Walks). 
• Isometric Core Engagement: Muscles hold tension to resist the weight's pull, building deep core strength and endurance. 
• Dynamic Stability: As you walk, your body constantly adjusts to the shifting load, improving coordination and balance. [1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8]
